description: This course examines the development of modern science as revealed by primary texts and analysis
of key episodes.  Beginning with Aristotle, Copernicus, and Galileo, students gain a deeper
understanding of the ideas, personalities, and events that shaped the emergence of the modern
scientific view of the natural world.  The course considers the historical, philosophical, and
theological dimensions of major revolutions in science along with important contemporary
developments.  Offered annually in the fall semester.
fullname: The Rise of Modern Science: Origins and Revolutions
